body:
We did that on purpose, since undercurls are generally blurry. If the majority will think that it's too thick, we can make them thinner. Just by looking at color of you undercurls you may notice that it actually the same as text as it should and has the color of underline.

Though, maybe just making it slightly thinner is an option.

I'll just leave it here so there could be a vote for that (top, middle, bottom) on the following pictures.

![picture](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/27620401/153324940-a4070c07-299c-42ca-b82e-933243bda6e4.png)

![picture](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/27620401/153324979-3f46b1f8-60b6-408a-9584-06165f136628.png)

I'd might middle, but I'm not sure.

For the above, middle or top. Not the bottom, looks to thick. It looks like a bolded undercurl.

> We did that on purpose, since undercurls are generally blurry.

It is a fine balance, in some ways it is an art-form to select thickness/thinness that satisfies (as we all experienced with native box-drawing chars). It takes a couple iterations.

I don't mind bluriness since GNOME Terminal (which has had undercurls for a long-time, 2012 I think) is a tad blurry:

![gterm_undercurl](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/11382509/153330592-cd896ac0-0425-4788-8e3e-5e5f7096a473.png)

Compared with Alacritty master:


![undercurl2](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/11382509/153330685-a4f64214-a458-4a26-85be-68fc266592eb.png)

Undercurls are shouty imo. I vote (if there is such a thing) to thin them out, like the middle images above.

Cheers.
This is all you @kchibisov, I don't care.
